skill.name: startup-metrics-framework
skill.description: Comprehensive guide to tracking, calculating, and optimizing key performance metrics for startups including SaaS, marketplace, consumer, and B2B business models from seed through Series A.
skill.summary: Track and optimize the right startup metrics at the right stage with formulas, benchmarks, and best practices for fundraising and operational excellence.
skill.author: wshobson

security_audit.summary: Static analyzer flagged 61 instances of backtick usage as external_commands, but manual review confirms these are Markdown code blocks containing mathematical formulas for business metrics, not executable shell commands. The skill is a legitimate educational resource about startup metrics frameworks with no security concerns.

medium_findings.title: Static Analyzer False Positives - Markdown Code Blocks
medium_findings.description: The static analyzer incorrectly flagged 61 instances of backtick usage as Ruby/shell command execution. Manual review confirms these are Markdown code block delimiters used for displaying mathematical formulas like 'MRR = Î£ (Active Subscriptions Ã— Monthly Price)', not executable code. This is standard Markdown formatting for code examples and formulas in documentation.

content.value_statement: Startup founders and operators often struggle to identify which metrics matter at each growth stage. This skill provides comprehensive formulas, benchmarks, and best practices for tracking SaaS, marketplace, and B2B metrics to make data-driven decisions and impress investors.
actual_capabilities: Calculate and explain key startup metrics including MRR, ARR, CAC, LTV, LTV:CAC ratio, and payback period
Provide stage-appropriate metric recommendations from pre-seed through Series A and beyond
Compare metrics against industry benchmarks for SaaS, marketplace, consumer, and B2B models
Analyze cash efficiency with burn rate, runway, and burn multiple calculations
Evaluate retention metrics including NDR, logo retention, and gross retention
Present metrics in investor-ready dashboard format
limitations: Does not connect to live data sources or APIs - provides formulas and guidance only
Does not generate actual dashboards or visualizations
Does not provide industry-specific benchmarks beyond general startup ranges
Does not replace financial advisors or accountants for tax and legal matters

use_cases.title: Founder Calculating Early-Stage Metrics
use_cases.description: A first-time founder at seed stage wants to understand which metrics investors care about and how to calculate them from their current data.
use_cases.target_user: Startup founders preparing for seed fundraising

use_cases.title: Growth Lead Optimizing CAC
use_cases.description: A growth or marketing lead needs to calculate CAC, LTV, and payback period to optimize marketing spend efficiency.
use_cases.target_user: Growth marketers and marketing operations teams

use_cases.title: CFO Preparing Investor Updates
use_cases.description: A CFO or finance lead needs to compile metrics for board meetings and investor updates with the right benchmarks.
use_cases.target_user: Finance leaders and CFOs at scaling startups

prompt_templates.title: Basic Metric Calculation
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me calculate our LTV:CAC ratio. We spend $50,000 on sales and marketing per month, acquire 40 new customers, have ARPU of $500, gross margin of 80%, and churn of 5% monthly. What is our CAC, LTV, and LTV:CAC ratio?
prompt_templates.scenario: Quick calculation of basic unit economics

prompt_templates.title: Stage-Appropriate Metrics
prompt_templates.prompt: We are a B2B SaaS company at the seed stage with $200K ARR. What are the 5-7 most important metrics we should track, and what are the target benchmarks we should aim for?
prompt_templates.scenario: Determining which metrics matter most at current growth stage

prompt_templates.title: Retention Analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: Our starting ARR was $500K. We had $80K new MRR, $40K expansion MRR, $20K contraction MRR, and $30K churned MRR this quarter. Calculate our Net Dollar Retention, Gross Retention, and Logo Retention. How do we compare to benchmarks?

prompt_templates.title: Investor Presentation Prep
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me create an investor metrics dashboard for our Series A pitch. Our metrics are: MRR $250K growing 18% MoM, ARR $3M growing 280% YoY, CAC $1,200, LTV $4,800, NDR 112%, logo retention 92%, burn $180K monthly with $3.2M cash. Format these appropriately and identify which metrics need improvement.

output_examples.input: Calculate our burn multiple. We have net burn of $150,000 per month and net new ARR of $100,000 per month.
output_examples.output: Your burn multiple is 1.5x, which falls in the 'Acceptable' range (1.5-2.0x). This means you are spending $1.50 to generate $1.00 of new ARR. For Series A companies, target a burn multiple below 2.0. To improve, focus on increasing net new ARR through better retention or expansion while managing burn.

output_examples.input: What metrics matter most for a marketplace business at seed stage?
output_examples.output: For a seed-stage marketplace, focus on these core metrics: 1) GMV and GMV growth rate (target 20%+ MoM early), 2) Take rate (typical range 10-25% depending on model), 3) Fill rate (% requests resulting in transaction - target >80%), 4) Repeat rate (% users transacting multiple times - target >60%), 5) Supply/demand balance. Revenue metrics become more important at Series A.

best_practices: Track 5-7 core metrics intensely rather than 50 metrics loosely - focus creates actionable insights
Align metric focus with company stage: retention and engagement at pre-seed, unit economics at seed, efficiency metrics at Series A
Review core metrics weekly and the full suite monthly to balance tactical and strategic visibility
anti_patterns: Focusing on vanity metrics like total users or page views without retention and engagement context
Ignoring unit economics (CAC, LTV) even at early stages - these matter from seed onward
Comparing yourself to inappropriate benchmarks - Series B targets do not apply to seed-stage companies

faq.question: What is the Rule of 40 and why does it matter?
faq.answer: The Rule of 40 states that a company's revenue growth rate plus profit margin should exceed 40%. It is a benchmark used by investors to evaluate the balance between growth and profitability, especially at Series B+ stage. A score above 40% is excellent, 20-40% is acceptable, and below 20% needs improvement.

faq.question: What is a good LTV:CAC ratio for startups?
faq.answer: A healthy LTV:CAC ratio is greater than 3.0, meaning customers generate three times the cost to acquire them. Ratios between 1.0-3.0 need improvement, and anything below 1.0 is unsustainable. The ratio should account for gross margin and customer lifetime.

faq.question: How do I calculate runway for my startup?
faq.answer: Runway is calculated by dividing your cash balance by your monthly net burn rate. For example, $3 million in cash divided by $150,000 monthly burn equals 20 months of runway. Maintain 12-18 months runway as a target to ensure sufficient time for fundraising or achieving profitability.

faq.question: What is Net Dollar Retention (NDR) and why is it important?
faq.answer: NDR measures revenue retained from existing customers including expansion, minus contraction and churn, expressed as a percentage. NDR above 100% indicates your existing customers are growing. Benchmarks: above 120% is best-in-class, 100-120% is good, below 100% needs improvement.

faq.question: How does burn multiple differ from burn rate?
faq.answer: Burn rate is the absolute amount of cash spent monthly. Burn multiple measures efficiency by comparing net burn to net new ARR - it shows how much you spend to generate each dollar of revenue. A burn multiple below 1.0 means you are generating more ARR than you are burning.

faq.question: Which metrics should I prioritize at pre-seed stage?
faq.answer: At pre-seed (product-market fit), focus on active user growth, user retention (Day 7 and Day 30), core engagement metrics, and qualitative feedback. Do not worry about revenue, CAC optimization, or detailed unit economics - these become important at later stages.
